stem: A 28-year-old G1P0 client with a history of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) at 28 weeks gestation presents with new-onset hypertension and proteinuria. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Diagnostic dilemma: Preeclampsia vs. SLE Nephritis.
Background: Chronic SLE (Lupus). Underweight.
Assessment: BP 152/98. Urine protein 3+. Client has a faint 'butterfly' rash on her face and reports joint pain.
Recommendation: Complement (C3/C4) and dsDNA labs.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 152/98, HR 92, RR 20. 2+ Edema in lower extremities.

actionOptions.text: Monitor Serum C3/C4 complement levels for improvement.
Administer Magnesium Sulfate bolus immediately for seizure prophylaxis.
Apply high-intensity UV blue lights for neonatal jaundice prevention.

parameterOptions.text: Serum Complement levels (C3/C4) and dsDNA titers.
Fetal growth and umbilical artery doppler (Risk of placental insufficiency).
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose.
Presence of a positive Babinski sign.

rationale.correct: This is an SLE (Lupus) Nephritis Flare (c2). SLE can mimic preeclampsia perfectly with hypertension, edema, and proteinuria. The differentiator in the EHR is the LOW Complement (C3/C4) levels and ELEVATED Anti-dsDNA, which indicate active autoimmune consumption/inflammation. In preeclampsia, complement levels are typically normal. Priority actions involve managing the autoimmune flare with steroids (a1) and tracking the inflammatory markers (a2). Parameter monitoring focuses on the disease activity (p1) and fetal safety (p2).
clinicalPearls: SLE flares in pregnancy increase the risk of fetal growth restriction and placental abruption.
A Lupus butterfly (malar) rash often reappears during an active flare.
Uric acid level is often high in preeclampsia but normal in a Lupus flare.

questionTrap.trap: Treating this as preeclampsia with Magnesium.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Look at the C3/C4! If those are LOW, it's an immune problem (Lupus). Magnesium won't fix an immune flare; steroids will.

mnemonic.title: Lupus Low
mnemonic.expansion: L-Low Complements (C3/C4). U-Uric acid is normal. P-Proteinuria is high. U-dsDNA up. S-Steroids fix it.
